ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Great opportunity to apply knowledge from other classes.

It was an excellent and very helpful experience for me to start my career in infectious disease modeling. I knew very little about modeling when I started this research rotation, but the primary instructor (Dr. Dan Weinberger) provided me with instructions and feedback which enabled me to keep this project moving forward.

Strengths-- Great introduction to benchwork and working with insects in a laboratory setting, encouraging and flexible PI (Doug Brackney). Weaknesses-- Along with long training period, not enough time to complete many tangible outcomes, especially considering the dependence on mosquito development times.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Excellent. Available for guidance when required.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Very helpful and flexible (as always) in choosing PIs and potential projects.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Opportunity to conduct your own research with direct contact with a Faculty member expert in the field you are interested in.

Research rotation for first-year PhD students. Although topics covered and skill sets ascertained will be widely varied, rotating with my PI/in my lab in particular would allow future students to gain tangible benchwork skills, using both in vivo (i.e. mosquito) and in vitro procedures.
